author: iannorden
content: The transition period would not be necessary in this case but perhaps it could be useful to collect metrics on mainnet before committing to 1559. It allows easing into 1559 and provides a period to catch potential issues or tweak parameters before a block is entirely composed of 1559 txs. As the spec is currently implemented the two hard forks are written into the code at once, so that unless something needs to be reverted or changed it continues directly into the 1559 only state.

content:
If there is no pain felt by tool developers and end-users, there will be no pressure to remove the legacy transactions. Service has to get significantly worse to get people to switch. I think somehow everyone in this room doesn't realize how sticky these sorts of things are. Please study the transitions in WINAPI this has been guiding a lot of my thinking. 16-bit WINAPI was around for a very long time. Today I just downloaded a WIN32 API app... There is no reason to keep this garbage in the code base, especially given the point of the change.

If the change is "too difficult" for people outside the protocol, then people have to put the funds to get the engineering done otherwise, by definition 1559 has failed. Actually, let's be more honest than that. If we live in a world where wallets aren't exposed to BASEFEE then the only point of BASEFEE is to burn ETH, fuck that.

author: afdudley
content:
The developers of wallets and other services in no way pay the fees for transactions, it's completely non-transitive, changing the fee structure doesn't force them to act at all.

What forces tooling to change is losing users to better tooling. But there is no sense in hoping some invisible hand makes the tooling, that's not how the tooling that we have today was developed. 

The EF made Mist, it was quickly unusable, and now we have metamask.

Exchanges want to do the smallest set of changes possible and since their whole business model is around listing new assets, they don't care if our code change causes a fork, it's actually better for them. If we want exchanges to switch transaction formats we must either provide all of the engineering support for them to do it or otherwise make it as seamless as possible. I believe a transition period does this. But as I stressed on the call, if we are going to make a change of this enormous magnitude The Ethereum Community at large has to be willing to support the integral systems that have no incentive to change. We can't just fuck over wallet devs, exchanges, etc for no reason, it will tank the price of Ether.

If we have two transaction types that means there will _always_ be someone who uses the old type, for no other reason than, "it works on my machine" that means we'll have two different code paths for no logical reason that do exactly the same thing. Why would we give people a choice when one of the choices is net worse for everyone. By giving that choice, we can assert that _someone_ will take it. If the choice is worse for the end-user, and worse for the community of people who pay transaction fees  then we must remove support of that option from tool devs. There is no reason to leave this up to chance, it adds long term system complexity for no reason.

content: Also - we successfully get exchanges to upgrade their node software every 6-12 months with no "penalty" other than they miss the hard fork.  This would be similar except there's the added efficiency benefit of 1559 txs if they upgrade early in the window
